metadata.case_name: Sohan Lal v. Jagan Nath & Union of India

facts.text: Jagan Nath registered as a refugee on December 31, 1947.

Government of India scheme for sale of box-type tenements in West Patel Nagar to displaced persons registered before August 15, 1948, gainfully employed; intended for those allotted agricultural land in East Punjab.
Procedure: Application, prima facie eligibility, deposit sale price (Rs. 5,600), verify eligibility, prepare list, pay ground rent, allot by lots if excess applicants.

Jagan Nath applied, prima facie eligible, deposited Rs. 5,600 sale price and ground rent, informed of allotment of two-roomed enclosed verandah box-type house, lots drawn February 15, 1952 at 3 p.m., allotted house No. 35 West Patel Nagar.
On May 10, 1952, Accommodation Officer removed Jagan Nath's family and belongings to house No. 35 in a truck; Jagan Nath and family entered possession.
Jagan Nath evicted from house No. 35 on September 27, 1952, by warrant dated September 11, 1952, under s. 25 of Ordinance III of 1952.
Possession of house No. 35 given to appellant Sohan Lal on October 3, 1952.
Sohan Lal, a displaced person, applied for allotment on February 27, 1952, deposited Rs. 5,600, complied with conditions, allotted house No. 35 on July 31, 1952; in possession since October 3, 1952.
Jagan Nath ineligible under scheme as allotted agricultural land in Hissar District; no letter of allotment issued to him; informed property could not be allotted.

Jagan Nath filed petition under Art. 226 in Punjab High Court (Civil Writ Application No. 314 of 1952), allowed by order dated April 30, 1953; ordered Union of India and Sohan Lal to restore possession of house No. 35 to Jagan Nath.
Special leave to appeal granted to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether proceedings under Art. 226 appropriate where serious dispute on questions of fact and title to property.
Whether writ of mandamus or order in nature of mandamus can issue against private individual like appellant without collusion with Union of India.
Whether Jagan Nath acquired title or rights to house No. 35 entitling restoration of possession.
Effect of illegal eviction under s. 3 Public Premises Eviction Act, 1950, when property now in possession of bona fide allottee.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred in ordering restoration via writ as serious dispute on facts and title; proper remedy is civil suit for title declaration.
No writ of mandamus against private individual; appellant in lawful possession without collusion with Union of India.

respondent_arguments.text: Entered possession not as trespasser but inducted by Accommodation Officer; evicted illegally without notice under s. 3 Public Premises Eviction Act, 1950; entitled to restoration.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 3 Public Premises Eviction Act, 1950 (Act No. XXVII of 1950)

respondent_arguments.text: Union of India and appellant should restore possession as eviction at instance of appellant.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Khushal Singh v. Shri Rameshwar Dayal; G. Kistareddy v. Commr. of City Police; Mohinder Singh v. State of Pepsu; Wazir Chand v. State of Himachal Pradesh

court_reasoning.text: Writ proceedings under Art. 226 not appropriate for disputed facts and title requiring civil suit; High Court should not declare title and order restoration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Questions of fact and law in dispute; prerogative writs not for passing decrees.

court_reasoning.text: Eviction contravened s. 3 Public Premises Eviction Act, illegal; mandamus could issue against Union of India if property still with them.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Illegal eviction but property now with appellant.

court_reasoning.text: No evidence or finding of collusion between appellant and Union of India; mandamus does not issue against private individual without public duty or collusion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant bona fide possessor like de facto office holder; quo warranto or suit needed.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant complied with conditions, letter of allotment issued; rights as against Jagan Nath to be decided in civil suit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Jagan Nath no letter of allotment; ineligible due to land in Hissar.

holdings.text: High Court erred in allowing Art. 226 petition and ordering restoration; such disputes to be resolved in civil court.
No mandamus against private individual in bona fide possession without collusion.

precedents_cited.case_name: Khushal Singh v. Shri Rameshwar Dayal, Deputy Commissioner, Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Support for restoration after illegal eviction

precedents_cited.case_name: G. Kistareddy v. Commr. of City Police, Hyderabad
precedents_cited.relevance: Support for restoration after illegal eviction

precedents_cited.case_name: Mohinder Singh v. State of Pepsu
precedents_cited.relevance: Support for restoration after illegal eviction

precedents_cited.case_name: Wazir Chand v. The State of Himachal Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Observations supporting restoration after illegal eviction
Mandamus not against de facto possessor unless colourable; quo warranto needed

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition filed; inappropriate for title disputes

statutes_cited.name: Public Premises Eviction Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Mandatory notice required before eviction; contravened, eviction illegal

statutes_cited.name: Ordinance III of 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Warrant of eviction issued under; but illegal due to non-compliance with 1950 Act

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order dated April 30, 1953, set aside. Disputes on title and facts to be resolved in civil suit; no mandamus against appellant.

key_quotes.text: We do not propose to enquire into the merits of the rival claims of title to the property in dispute set up by the appellant and Jagan Nath.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Declines to adjudicate title in writ proceedings

key_quotes.text: Normally, a writ of mandamus does not issue to or an order in the nature of mandamus is not made against a private individual.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The eviction of Jagan Nath was in contravention of the express provisions of s. 3 of the Public Premises Eviction Act. His eviction, therefore, was illegal.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Acknowledges illegality but denies remedy via writ against possessor
